ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 12. I used this course as my capstone, and found that the variety of client projects offered was a realasset. I appreciated the opportunity to work on a client-driven project, and gained a lot of knowledge (interpersonal communications, database and document formatting, federal funding programs) during the research and writing process.
This was not my first time taking the course, so I did not attend class.
Great class - a lot of interesting guest speakers, cool topics covered, smooth process with matching folks with the clients. The most value for me was definitely the client project.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Actually getting to engage in real environmental problems. invaluable.
Getting to work with a real client and real issue.
Practical experience, ability to travel to clients for final presentations.

The ability to work with a client on an environmental issue that was personally important. The clinic instructors were responsive to student feedback, and were supportive of student needs when interacting with clients (including acting as a sounding board for project ideas and brainstorming solutions to communications issues).
This course offers valuable experience and a tangible product.
The support from my group during our project,as well as from Josh, was incredibly helpful.
The guest lectures were really interesting
The range of great client projects, and I was very happy with the one I ended up with.
Conversations with clients and in person meeting.

My project turned out really well overall. There was some uncertainty and we had our frustrations, but in the end I was satisfied with the work I had done and the things I had learned. Kudos to all three instructors for putting together great lectures and providing good supervision.

This is not an instructional course, so everything revolved around our individual projects and clients. Therefore, we really learned how to work as a group with a client on a particular project that had meaning beyond the walls of Yale. It was great real world experience.
Gained good exposure to non profits I was interested in working for.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The supplemental classes on various aspects (lobbying, communications, etc) should be voluntary.

Maybe some of the class periods could be used for group work where the professors could come around and check in on us while we are actually working (as opposed to just asking how we're doing in meetings).
More sharing of experiences, already early on in the semester, of the groups and their clients.

I would have personally been more interested in having an extra class on foundations of U.S. environmental law and policy rather than a longer focus on environmental campaigns. However, I know that there is another environmental law and policy course that students can take if it fits into their schedule. I would have also liked to have more of an interaction with the law school students, and to learn more about opportunities for future classes/workshops at the law school.
Materials covered in lecture were often unrelated to projects.

I have no idea how to fix this, but it seems to me that some projects end up being much more than 120 hours, and others just squeak to that amount. Somehow, projects need to be better evaluated for the approximate amount of they will require, because it is difficult, as a student, to tell your client that you are going to do less than they have asked for (and often, you don't know this until 75% of the way through the term, when you are 50% done with your hours :) ).

The Boot Camp seemed quite ambitious with how much information it was trying to pack into an hour or so. I ended up feeling like I didn't get a whole lot out of it because it was so compressed and the pace was so fast. I think covering less, but going at a slower speed where there's more time for questions, would have been better for me.I think the instructors could have maybe talked to us a little bit more about career/professional development with clients. E.g. how/when to talk about how the work could be conveyed on a resume, if/how it's okay to ask for introductions to their colleagues or for career advice, etc. I think maybe spending 20-30 minutes in some class (at the beginning of the semester) talking about that would have been useful.
One or two of the lectures didn't interest me very much, but it's such a diverse class that I think that is ok. There was something for everyone.

It would be nice to work our projects into class lectures a little more often, and it would be nice to have some more in-person project check-ins from the instructors. They were offered, but it would be nice to have a little bit more research guidance in the future during class time. i found that I was learning on the fly and could have benefited from some more research advice from the instructors who surely have much more experience than I with client relationships and completing projects.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Overall I did not find myself able to relate the class material to the actual client project my group and I were working on. Maybe survey "most needed topics" for lecture and sprinkle them throughout the semester instead of at the end?
More discussions would be good.
N/A
Course lectures were valuable but broad in scope. We covered a wide range of areas; some of which were directly applicable to my area of interest.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Working with stakeholders, working on policy challenges in the reality of the world.
Working with a real client is a strength of FES.
This course is my capstone as an MEM at the School of Forestry.
I like working on projects for clients, especially if they have a point of view!
interested in energy policy, and i found what i wanted. be sure to keep offering energy-related projects! there's definitely demand for them, IMO.
This class provided me with a real world application of the other classes I took this semester, and the project I chose really synthesized their concepts.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To have a capstone.
Experience with client.
This course provided me with the opportunity to work on an applied project, gain experience working with a client, and research a topic that was relevant to my area of study.
As a capstone and to create a product
To have the opportunity to work on a project for a real-world client, and because I'd heard really good things about the class in the past.
to get the real world experience i came to grad school for!also because i'm required to take a capstone.
I wanted to see what environmental advocacy would be like on a daily basis in a professional setting, and if it's the kind of work I'd like to do throughout my career.
To gain real world experience with an influential NGO.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes and exceeded it.

Yes, I learned about client communications and gained knowledge of current conservation management/funding programs relevant to my project. I wished that I could have devoted more time to researching these programs once my team identified them, but we had a relatively steep learning curve in the beginning of the semester.
Yes
I learned a lot about my project topic think I would have benefitted from a basic legal introduction
Yep.
Yes.
yes
Yes, although what students learn is highly dependent on their group projects.
The course met my expectations

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Its all group work. advantages- learning from smart people. disadvantages- so many group meetings.
Scheduling and communication sometimes difficult. Division of labor is another obstacle that should be hammered out early in the semester.

Coordinating group work sessions was difficult at times given other commitments and hectic schedules. However, I felt that the members of my group worked well together and were supportive of each othersâ needs.

Advantages: never-ending support (and sometimes commiseration), getting to know new people, benefiting from others' expertiseDisadvantages: making sure everyone is on the same page can be time-consuming, and sometimes it is difficult to move ahead because it makes sense if everyone moves forward (with the stage of research, writing, etc.) at the same time. Otherwise, a super awesome group experience!
We were able to get a lot done. We worked well together but there is no way to evaluate our group members, which I wish I could have done.
It worked well and we struggled sometimes but overall it was great to improve my group work skills.

Advantages - I really got to learn a lot from my peers and their existing knowledge. They really kept the project moving throughout the semester.Disadvantages - the small annoyances of working with people. For example, one group member was literally always late to every meeting or expert interview we had.And it was also just difficult to weave together different sections (that we had each written) and to go through multiple phases of editing as a group (taking turns with the document). Fortunately we gave ourselves enough time for that and I think it turned out well in the end.I think the guidance in class was mainly about relations between the students and client, but it might have also been interesting/useful to talk about how to have a successful/functioning group (just as students).

my group was awesome. everyone was positive and enthusiastic, and we worked really well together. no real major problems.i appreciate the group work, as this is something i'll likely be encountering during my career.

The advantage was learning how to coordinate logistics for a semester-long project with fellow students. However, that was one of the greatest challenges, as well. Our project's workload was easily divided among our group members, and we could each work relatively autonomously on our individual parts throughout the semester. It was hard to synthesize our work, however, one the writing was complete because we all have different writing styles, etc.
Our group worked well together but focused on very different research areas.

Having a team was a valuable part of the work experience and made working for a client more manageable (and likely more realistic). That said, it was occasionally hard to coordinate meeting times and ensure we were on the same page about progress.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: MAKE SURE YOU PICK A PROJECT YOU WANT TO DEVOTE YOUR SEMESTER TO. this class would be a complete nightmare, worst case scenario course if you were working on something you weren't passionate about.

Strongly recommend to clarify with your group and client EXACTLY (or as close as possible) where the project is headed EARLY in the semester.Also, deadlines throughout the semester with your client are helpful to check on progress and get feedback which is very important.
Be careful in selecting your client. This makes most of the experience during the course.

Your client is the most important factor in making this course a meaningful experience. If the project is clearly defined, fits with your academic interests, and the client is able to communicate their needs, the process of creating a fully-developed product can be incredibly rewarding. The clinic instructors are incredibly supportive in making sure that the experience is valuable.
DO IT! Just make sure you have plenty of time in the semester to devote to this.
Break up the product into smaller parts as much as possible. Try to communicate confusion and concerns as early as possible.
Have incremental deliverables throughout the course, even if just for the instructor and not the client.

It's a great class, make sure you really think about who you want your client to be. Communicate clearly about expectations with client and group members from the very beginning. Try to frontload hours as much as you can.
take it!
Wait for your second year to take this course. I think I would have gotten much more out of the clinic had I waited.
Great course. Gained exposure to a nonprofit I was interested in working for. Be prepared for self directed work.
